issue.title: Add Lens Distortion Estimator plugin
issue.body:
This is a new plugin that can be used to estimate distortion of the objective lens of your camera by taking a photo of stars, picking them (by hand) to match to Stellarium's simulation, and generate a distortion model for use with the lensfun library. How to use it is written in the About tab of the config dialog.

It currently works (only rectilinear lenses are supported for now), but I'm not completely satisfied with the UI, particularly for initial positioning of the image in the sky, and also for picking the points. Maybe you can come up with suggestions on how to make it easier to use (maybe some dragging to move and rotate the image? is there any object with such capabilities in Stellarium?).

If the instructions in the About text are unclear, I'd also like to get your feedback.

Another incompleteness is that the core dependency, GSL, is not downloaded in any way, only located via `find_package()`. If it's missing, you can only fit manually, which is very tedious and generally unwanted since you can simply build with GSL support and click the semi-magic button.

One more dependency, exiv2, is not so much required, but it lets you easily set simulation time to the photo time from EXIF tags. This dependency is also only optionally used.

I'm not sure what we want to do with these dependencies: download from the releases? For exiv2 it seems easy, but GSL doesn't release binaries — should we build them on each rebuild of Stellarium, or maybe host the binaries we build once? Or maybe use CPM for both (which would add more time to the build process)?

pull_request.title: GUI scalability and styling improvements
pull_request.body:
These commits prepare the GUI for transformation into a more scaling-friendly version. In particular, I'm planning to get rid of all the hard-coded pixel-based sizes that already work badly with increased font sizes, and replace them with proper `QLayout`-based size management.

My main concern, why I'm making a PR for this change, is that something might get broken or changed in an undesirable way (such as the GPS button that became flat, which is fixed by the 4th commit).

There's also a good side effect: at least on Linux/X11 the color picking buttons are now flat-colored, showing the exact color they are set to instead of the confusing desaturated gradient as there was before.

repo.name: stellarium
repo.description: Stellarium is a free GPL software which renders realistic skies in real time with OpenGL. It is available for Linux/Unix, Windows and MacOSX. With Stellarium, you really see what you can see with your eyes, binoculars or a small telescope.

repo.name: stellarium
repo.description: Stellarium is a free GPL software which renders realistic skies in real time with OpenGL. It is available for Linux/Unix, Windows and macOS. With Stellarium, you really see what you can see with your eyes, binoculars or a small telescope.

- [ ] Are possibly unused includes removed?


This is an automatically generated QA checklist based on modified files.

issue.title: Qt5 QML
issue.body:
According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/issues/2739#issuecomment-1272601781 QML is only supported with Qt6. What specifically stops using QML with Qt5 instead of QtScript?

According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/blob/2533f48decea2543e2a8a4c8e157f3fc6094acdc/CMakeLists.txt#L480-L482 it should work

Ref https://bugs.gentoo.org/916113 - QtScript is going to be removed from Gentoo

comment.body:
ok, I see the problem.

If the script itself called `core.pauseScript()`, stellarium could do the same explicit event processing like it does now using agent, and similar to what it does in `core.wait()`, even in Qt6, until user resumes it via GUI.

However, there's no good way to pause the script via GUI, when the script didn't expect that itself. The best option I see is to check isPaused in every JS-callable function of StelMainScriptAPI. That does somewhat decrease the frequency when exactly the script would be paused

comment.body: @gzotti who is supposed to call `resumeScript()`? I see the function defined, but noone seems to call it, so after a script called `pauseScript()` there's no way for it to resume?

issue.title: Qt5 QML
issue.body:
According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/issues/2739#issuecomment-1272601781 QML is only supported with Qt6. What specifically stops using QML with Qt5 instead of QtScript?

According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/blob/2533f48decea2543e2a8a4c8e157f3fc6094acdc/CMakeLists.txt#L480-L482 it should work

Ref https://bugs.gentoo.org/916113 - QtScript is going to be removed from Gentoo

comment.body: QML-based scripting has lost the ability to pause/resume script execution. Until a JS genius fixes that for us, we recommend "staying at Qt5" (implying "using QtScript", although QML should technically work with Qt5.15) when this is essential for some users.  Else, some syntactic changes (3D vectors, colors) can be overcome by applying common new syntax in both versions.

comment.body:
That seems to imply Stellarium with Qt6 QML does not have the same limitations/less functionality as a theoretical Qt5 QML version?

@DarthGandalf: Possible, the only downside is potentially pulling in both qtwebengine slots for some users - but they can disable it, and QtWebEngine5 will only be the next tracker to identify porting stragglers.

comment.body: I have zero time this week for fixes. What kinds of error appear when you build with Qt5 and QML script? This is just the option nobody wants, given the demise of pauseScript() in QML.

issue.title: Qt5 QML
issue.body:
According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/issues/2739#issuecomment-1272601781 QML is only supported with Qt6. What specifically stops using QML with Qt5 instead of QtScript?

According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/blob/2533f48decea2543e2a8a4c8e157f3fc6094acdc/CMakeLists.txt#L480-L482 it should work

Ref https://bugs.gentoo.org/916113 - QtScript is going to be removed from Gentoo

comment.body:
> Unfortunately, Qt6 applications will look bad in Qt5-based DEs for some time to come, which means Qt6 build option would be a bad default until well into 2024.

Stellarium does its own UI, independent from the Qt widgets theme, so this is not actually a concern here. So I guess I should just disable the Qt5 option for the Stellarium Gentoo package

issue.title: Qt5 QML
issue.body:
According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/issues/2739#issuecomment-1272601781 QML is only supported with Qt6. What specifically stops using QML with Qt5 instead of QtScript?

According to https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/blob/2533f48decea2543e2a8a4c8e157f3fc6094acdc/CMakeLists.txt#L480-L482 it should work

Ref https://bugs.gentoo.org/916113 - QtScript is going to be removed from Gentoo

comment.body:
1) There is no such thing as maintenance mode in a source-based distribution. Every package we provide must be able to build with an up to date toolchain, newer versions of dependencies that may not be able to sit side-by-side on a system without downstream modifications. We can not just let old packages sit there like in a binary distro.
2) There is no such thing as a clean sweep switch from Qt5 to Qt6 for distributions, it is a drawn-out process. Sometimes upstreams even need to be made aware of the need for porting in the first place, sometimes no one answers anymore, that's when you flag stuff for removal downstream.
3) QtScript is "part of" 5.15 LTS, but it has not received any fixes in years - it is deprecated since 5.5 already, but even then had only been provided for compatibility to Qt 4 in the fist place. It is a dead end with many known issues and that makes it a prime target to identify troubled reverse dependencies early, and get downstream maintainers to communicate with upstreams. Stellarium, therefore, showed up in that list.

The good news is that you've already ported to Qt6, and Gentoo's downstream maintainer for Stellarium provides that option. Unfortunately, Qt6 applications will look bad in Qt5-based DEs for some time to come, which means Qt6 build option would be a bad default until well into 2024.

So, the worst thing that would happen to Stellarium is to look slightly out of place. It is, however, the only piece of software I've seen to choose to keep a QtScript codebase in the process of porting to Qt6, that makes it the odd one out.

issue.title: Add Lens Distortion Estimator plugin
issue.body:
This is a new plugin that can be used to estimate distortion of the objective lens of your camera by taking a photo of stars, picking them (by hand) to match to Stellarium's simulation, and generate a distortion model for use with the lensfun library. How to use it is written in the About tab of the config dialog.

It currently works (only rectilinear lenses are supported for now), but I'm not completely satisfied with the UI, particularly for initial positioning of the image in the sky, and also for picking the points. Maybe you can come up with suggestions on how to make it easier to use (maybe some dragging to move and rotate the image? is there any object with such capabilities in Stellarium?).

If the instructions in the About text are unclear, I'd also like to get your feedback.

Another incompleteness is that the core dependency, GSL, is not downloaded in any way, only located via `find_package()`. If it's missing, you can only fit manually, which is very tedious and generally unwanted since you can simply build with GSL support and click the semi-magic button.

One more dependency, exiv2, is not so much required, but it lets you easily set simulation time to the photo time from EXIF tags. This dependency is also only optionally used.

I'm not sure what we want to do with these dependencies: download from the releases? For exiv2 it seems easy, but GSL doesn't release binaries — should we build them on each rebuild of Stellarium, or maybe host the binaries we build once? Or maybe use CPM for both (which would add more time to the build process)?

comment.body:
Great plugin, thanks!

> So I suppose an XML output for pasting into lensfun's DB will suffice for now, until someone comes up with ideas for a better UX.

+1 for XML
